event: slipping on wet grass and falling on his left side
no ecchymosis to the abdomen, flank or thigh
radiograph of his pelvis revealed an undisplaced fracture of his left acetabulum
warmed Hartmanns one litre infusion commenced
referred to the Orthopaedic on call team
blood pressure dropped to 75/51 mm Hg
intensive care, orthopaedic and general registrar attended the patient
left lower abdominal quadrant and upper thigh swollen with ecchymosis
two adult therapeutic doses of platelets transfused
CT abdomen confirmed the fracture of the left acetabulum
significant haematoma on left pelvic sidewall adjacent to the fracture
8 mm enhancing nodule suggestive of an internal iliac artery pseudoaneurysm
ill-defined blush of contrast within the haematoma
extra-peritoneal haematoma inseparable from the bladder
transferred to the intensive care unit
gelfoam embolization of anterior and posterior division segmental branches of the left internal iliac artery
uncontrollable bleeding from his pin site
continuous pressure applied to the wound
